reviewText: I watch it on the NFL Network and when I found out that A Football Life was available on DVD, I knew I had to buy it. It has great stories on football legends.
summary: A must have for football fans
Title: N/A

reviewText: Any fan of NFL Films will not be disappointed ... the traditional drama and high quality is maintained in each story.  People have told me that this is not for casual football fans, but only for those fantantics that find themselves having withdrawal symtoms in March and April and needing a football fix to get them through to the start of the pre-season ... this will help.

reviewerName: John T. R. Gorman "John Lee Booker"
reviewText: For starters, here's the heretofore missing program list for this magnificent 4-disc set:DISC 1 - Bill Belichick, (Parts 1-2)Reggie White and Jerome BrownDisc 2 - Kurt WarnerWalter PaytonEd SabolDisc 3 - Mike DitkaTom LandryAl Davis (profile)DISC 4 - BONUS: Unedited, unscripted Al Davis interview by the late NFL Films president, Steve Sabol.This point, above all, must be understood first. "Shut up and watch!"  No matter which team(s) you love -- or despise -- you're going to find each subject in this, the inaugural season of NFL Films' "A Football Life" enthralling.I know, I know. There are some folks profiled here that are polarizing figures, either due to their personalities, or simply by virtue of NFL rivalries themselves.Fans of the Eagles or Redskins, for instance, might gag at the very idea of watching a movie on their arch-rival, the late Cowboys' head coach, Tom Landry, for 42 minutes. The Bears' often abrasive, and foul-mouthed player/coach, Mike Ditka, annoys many. Trust me on this: As THE world's most devoted Packers' fan, I know that firsthand. Moreover, since Jerry Jones took over in Dallas, I can't *stand* the Cowboys myself, but... I reminded myself of my own advice. Shut up and watch, John!Point being, no matter who is the program's subject, the late Steve Sabol, and his dad, Ed, God rest them both, make each episode well worth your time to watch, again and again. Now on to the many goodies within.1. BILL BELICHICK - With fascinating results, the Patriots' head coach agreed to have NFL Films follow him literally everywhere for the entire 2009 season. Whether Bill was at home, on a golf course, in Patriots' team meetings, practices, or games, the good and bad are all there, for about 90 superbly-edited minutes in total, and I really enjoyed it. (The season ends with New England getting blown out in a playoff loss at home vs. Baltimore.)Smart though Belichick is, I wish NFL Films would've chosen a different head coach. I say that with every good reason. For the record, here are the cold, hard facts.In 2007 Bill Belichick and his staff were found guilty of cheating by the NFL, by stealing their opponents play-calling signals through illegal filming, in a scandal called, "Spygate". After the Packers caught a New England assistant red-handed, doing this illegal filming, the NFL began a serious investigation.The Pats were shown to have been cheating for years. The Steelers started the allegations in 2002, the year Belichick's Patriots won the first of three different (2002, 04-05) Super Bowls. It was demonstrated to the league that The Patriots had illegally filmed the 2002 NFC champion Rams' Super Bowl run-throughs.Belichick thus lost all of my respect. The Patriots and coach Belichick were severely punished with record-high fines totaling $750,000, plus the loss of their 2008 first-round draft selection. Belichick and Pats' owner, Robert Kraft were made to publicly apologize to the entire NFL, and its fans.Former Miami Dolphins head coach Don Shula, who coached the 1972 Dolphins team to the "perfect season", commented on the scandal, saying: "The Spygate thing has diminished what they've accomplished. You would hate to have that attached to your accomplishments, (but) they've got it. It's the same thing as putting an asterisk by Barry Bonds' home run record."2. REGGIE WHITE and JEROME BROWN - As you'd expect, I honed in on this because Reggie was instrumental in my Packers' return to "Titletown", with our victory in Super Bowl XXXI (1996). What I found in addition to that, was a deeply emotional tale of the friendship between White and Brown while both were members of the Eagles. Both found greatness, but were sadly denied length of years.One thing you should know about the respect that Reggie White commanded. I met that amazingly Christian man at the Green Bay funeral of  the Packers' legendary, retired # 66, Ray Nitschke, in March, 1998. Ray was the Pack's middle linebacker throughout the Lombardi Era and beyond, from 1958-73. Nitschke had not only become close to Reggie White, but was, quite literally, my "Extra Dad" from the time I was age twelve 'til Ray died thirty years later. Thus, Reggie and I were huddled alone, sharing some private thoughts about Ray, and both choking back tears.Whoosh! Three photographers swooped down upon us, their cameras clicking, flashes blinding. Then, Reggie White's eyes flashed also, in genuine anger at this intrusion. Turning to those three cameramen, his voice thundered,. "NOT TODAY, FELLOWS! NOT TODAY!" Those photographers apologized in unison, while simultaneously running away for fear of White. They should have; Reggie's vocal sonic boom must've been heard from Green Bay to Chicago!I bought every edition of the Green Bay and Milwaukee papers the next morning to read about Ray's funeral. Every photo that I saw those three cameramen shoot that day got published... except those of Reggie and me. Sad, in a way, because I'd love to have just one of those photos today!3. KURT WARNER - If this story fails to move you, someone had better check to see if you're even breathing. Kurt Warner met Brenda Meoni, a divorcee with two kids, while both were dancing at a country music bar in 1996. Given Brenda's striking beauty, many men had danced with Brenda before Kurt met her, but as soon as other guys learned that Brenda had two young kids, (one with significant disabilities), they'd scatter. Kurt didn't. In fact, he not only married Brenda in 1997, but he adopted those kids, who adored Kurt from Day One. Heck, he was only 21.The football half of Kurt Warner's tale would get thrown away as too corny if it was a movie script, but it's all true. Warner went from working the night shift as a stock boy at a local Hy-Vee grocery store to quarterback. First, for the Arena League's Iowa Barnstormers, then as backup QB for the St. Louis Rams in 1999. "So what?", you say? Hardly!When Rams' starting QB, Trent Green, was badly injured early in the first game that season, Warner stepped in. In his first full three games as a starter, Kurt Warner threw three touchdown passes apiece, an NFL record that may never be broken. The Rams won the Super Bowl that year; Warner won the NFL's Triple Crown: First, the NFL's Bart Starr Man of the Year Award, (for charity work), the NFL's MVP Award, and the Super Bowl MVP Award, too.4. WALTER PAYTON - Walter was once the holder of many NFL rushing records, including most career rushing yards. All of his records have been broken, and Payton himself died of cancer in 1999. Thus, does this Chicago Bear still matter? You're darned right he does! (Remember, this is the devout Packers' fan saying so!) Walter matters as the best back of the eighties, some say the best ever. Personally, my choice for best-ever is Barry Sanders, but I grant that an argument can be made for Walter Payton instead. Walter matters for his dominance in that era. Walter matters for his honesty and courage.5. ED SABOL - The fact that pro football is played the way it is, and has gained its incredible popularity is due to NFL Films' founder Ed Sabol, and his son Steve, who succeeded him. The NFL and its fans owe these greatly creative men a huge debt.It was Ed who convinced the NFL to allow Sabol's crews to film each team's games on Sunday. First, this allowed Ed to air a weekly NFL highlights TV show, which I never missed. All those great slow-motion shots, and the camera following a spiraling pass' arc as it slices through the air to land in a receiver's arms for the winning TD. All backed by NFL Films' composer Sam Spence's stirring music? You can't beat that! Of greater importance, each NFL team agreed to share Ed Sabol's game films with each other, which totally changed the game!Every team's coaches and players now could study one another's game plans via celluloid. This made every game more competitive than ever before!6. MIKE DITKA -  He chomps cigars and curses on-camera in the studio. As a Hall Of Fame TE, this Bears/Cowboys player's hard-nosed play earned him the nickname, "Iron Mike". As coach, "Iron Mike" Ditka kicks and screams on the sidelines, his face contorted in anger's color, a brilliant, cherry red. When his own wife, Diana, is asked, "Do you call your husband, 'Mike' or 'Coach'?" She calmly replies, "A**hole!", then cracks up laughing.So, who is Ditka? One abrasive, no-nonsense winner, who played for both George Halas and Tom Landry. He is the only Head Coach in the Super Bowl Era to score a touchdown in a Super Bowl as a player. (Super Bowl VI, 1971).Mike is big-hearted. He founded, and largely funds himself, a charity that cares for aging ex-NFL players that are otherwise destitute, and in need of ongoing medical care. Yeah, he's said and done many things with which I disagree, but taking on the care for destitute players? Gotta love him for that.7. TOM LANDRY - Tom helped Ditka earn his only Super Bowl ring as a player, (Ditka won one as head coach of the 1985 Bears, too.) Yet Landry's career with the Dallas Cowboys was much more than that. Landry's record 29 years as head coach, with his record 20 straight winning seasons, are  likely never to be equaled. WARNING! Jerry Jones appears briefly in this film, describing how he became the Cowboys' new owner and fired Tom Landry on the same day, 2-26-89, a.k.a. "The Saturday Night Massacre", as Cowboy fans call it. Jones' describes how he fired Landry, with Jerry warmly smiling, as if he truly enjoyed dismissing Landry. Jones' grin didn't fit his tale; It was actually sickening.I showed that video to two neighbors of mine who are real-life CSI. I did this because Jerry Jones' attitude in firing Tom Landry reminded me of the criminals on the fictional CSI shows who enjoy the cruelty of their TV crimes. (Jones even had NFL Films tape Landry cleaning out the desk in his office. The poor guy was humiliated!) My CSI neighbors agreed that Jones' attitude and behavior towards Tom Landry was "chillingly mean-spirited" and "despicable".  I agreed.8. and 9. AL DAVIS  - Okay, okay... Just as with Jerry Jones, you either love the late Oakland Raiders' owner or you hate his guts. I'm the rare bird that's a bit of both with Al. I loved that he was the only guy in league history to have been an assistant coach, the youngest-ever head coach, the AFL Commissioner, and then an owner. I loved that he was the first to fearlessly hire minority head coaches -- NOT because they were Hispanic (Tom Flores), or Black (Art Shell), but because they were great coaches. Davis was admirably honest about his many successes, and often-colossal mistakes as well.Above all, Al Davis generously rewarded those who were loyal to his Raiders. Heck, when one player's father needed heart surgery, Al flew the player's parents into Oakland and personally set the father up with Oakland's top heart surgeon. Davis himself  paid the surgeon's bills, hospital bills, plus all the parents' hotel bills, too.I hated, however, when Al Davis sued the NFL, a couple of cities, and seemed to have spent more time in courtrooms than locker rooms. In those later years, Davis simply became obnoxious. (He admitted as much during the interview with Steve Sabol.) At that time, Davis' Raiders set a record for futility that will hopefully never be equaled by any team. They lost at least eleven games or more for an unbelievable seven years straight, (2003-2009, 29 wins-83 losses, a staggeringly poor 74% loss rate!). What didn't help matters is that head-honcho Davis fired coaches on average of one per year during that time.That's it! If you've read this far, then thank you! I wanted to give you as much information as I could. Amazon will ask if you found this review helpful, and I hope that you have.
summary: No Matter Which NFL Team You Love, This is NFL Films' Best Series Yet!

reviewText: Excellent DVD on some of footballs greatest legends. A very well done series and a must see for any fan.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Each documentary is very well-done. Legends from Walter Payton to Tom Landry,and the lives and bond between Jerome Brown and Reggie White to HOFer Mike Ditka are each detailed with equal detail.However, the true gems of this set are the fascinating inside look at Bill Belichick and an exclusive, lengthy 1997 interview with the late Al Davis. Additionally, very neat packaging make this well worth the price.
summary: A Great Buy For The True NFL Fan!

reviewText: I bought primarily for my favorite athlete of all time, Walter Payton.  His story is very well captured in the series showing his remarkable hard work and achievements.  The other stories are all good and interesting.  I learned a lot of details that I did not know before.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am so very glad NFL Films decided to release this anthology series on DVD.  Although Blu-ray would  have been nice, indeed, it is better than nothing!!!!!!!  This is worth the time and viewing.  The quality, when presented through an HD home theater setup, is really glaringly wonderful.  It may not be a Blu-ray presentation, but this DVD fills the bill for me!!!!!  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!!!!!

reviewText: Well done series, the pieces on Walter Payton and Jerome Brown/Reggie White literally brought tears to my eyes, great players and great men cut down in life way too soon.  The piece on Ed Sabol is also very good, who would have thought he would have outlasted his son Steve, tragically cut down by cancer as well.
